abstract.para: When a system needs to represent a range of different document types, each document type can be represented by a completely separate declarations.

section.title: Problem
section.para: A system needs to represent different types of information. This information may be used at different times, or may be used by different parts of the system.

section.title: Context
section.para: Systems which need to represent a variety of information at different times or places.

section.title: Forces
section.para: Processing and authoring of documents can be simplified if different document types are used to represent different sets of data.

section.title: Solution
section.para: Use different document types to represent different sets of data within the system.

section.title: Examples
section.para: In a payroll system, data about the Employees, and data about the hours they work can be represented by separate documents.

example.title: Employees.dtd:
example.programlisting:
<!ELEMENT Employee (Name, HourlyRate)> <!ATTLIST Employee id ID #REQUIRED>
<!ELEMENT Name (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT HourlyRate (#PCDATA)>

example.title: HoursWorked.dtd:
example.programlisting:
<!ELEMENT PayPeriod (Employee+)> <!ATTLIST PayPeriod StartDate #CDATA EndDate #CDATA>
<!ELEMENT Employee (HoursWorked)> <!ATTLIST Employee id NMTOKEN>
<!ELEMENT HoursWorked (#PCDATA)>

section.title: Discussion
section.para: If different people will authoring the different types of documents it is a good idea to have completely separate document types, because authors will not need to be exposed to parts of the document types that are not needed.
Having separate document types allows the different DTDs to be versioned independently.

section.title: Related Patterns
section.para: Universal Root allows multiple types of data under one document root. Multi Root Document Types allows for multiple types of documents to be declared in a single declaration.
